newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-"I NEVER HAD A DRINK PROBLEM," CLOUGH SAYS.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-"I NEVER HAD A DRINK PROBLEM," CLOUGH SAYS.

text.p: Brian Clough, the irrepressible former coach of Nottingham Forest and one of the all-time greats of English soccer management, has denied he was ever an alcoholic.
"I didn't have a problem with drink," he told British satellite TV station Sky News.
"There's a social side to football as there is to most careers and I've been known to have the odd glass of champagne and with every good reason to have it.

"I did go through a stage where possibly instead of having one glass of champagne I was having two and that inevitably became three, and all that, but it was all part and parcel of the job, an accepted part and parcel of every day life."
Asked about his earlier admission that his family had been concerned about the amount he drank, Clough said: "That's perfectly true. I've cut it out totally."
He laughed off rumours he had been seriously ill, saying: "I wasn't at death's door for a start.
"I had a knee operation that set me back a bit but if people want to write about me at death's door, good luck to them. I hope everybody feels as good as I feel."
Clough is one of only three men, along with 1930s manager Herbert Chapman and new Newcastle boss Kenny Dalglish, to have won the English league title with two different clubs.
He guided Derby to championship success in 1972 and then repeated the feat with Forest six years later.
Clough, renowned for his straight-talking approach to life, began his managerial career at Hartlepool aged 29 after a serious knee injury ended his days as a player.
He then moved to Derby and had spells at Brighton and Leeds before arriving at Forest in 1975, guiding them to successive European Cup triumphs in 1979 and 1980.
He managed Forest for 18 years, stepping down in 1993 when they were relegated from the premier league.
